segments.text: I'm asking them because from your point of view, maybe a little bit different from somebody who actually fought or from one of the administrators or higher officials who actually implemented the war.
In your opinion, why were we in Vietnam?
I think we were there because of the perceived notion of the dominance theory.
I think that policy at that time was we've got to stop the spread of communism.
And we talked about supporting our democratic allies in Vietnam.
I wasn't too impressed with our democratic allies in Vietnam.
They were a sleazy bunch to tell you the truth.
But it was a place where

At that time, at any rate, the country thought, or the government thought, you know, if this goes down, it's going to be Cambodia, and then it's going to be Thailand, and then it's going to be Singapore, and then right down the line, I think that's what it would be.
And do you think we were justified in being there?
And why do you think we lost?
Because we didn't decide to kick their butts.
We elected to fight their kind of war.
You can read the history of it if you didn't know it.
And you can also read the history of the war.
We'd gone north and taken care of them.
And we would have been the villains in the eyes of the world for about six months.
And everybody would have forgotten it.
And everybody would have been home.
There's been a terrible carnage among Vietnamese civilians, particularly in the, well, particularly in the north, but every place.
They've taken a lot of American lives and shortened the war and would not have destroyed that country.
And, you know, if we were going to go to war, we should have gone to war.
And if we weren't going to war, we should have stayed home.
Let the little brown devils fight themselves.
You know, whatever they want to do is fine.
You can't justify some of the things.
I mean, how can you justify that?
You can't justify killing some babies like that.
But if you've been there, you can understand how it happened.
Because, you know, if a cute little eight-year-old kid comes into your dining hall and puts the box down that's got 15, 20 pounds of TNT in it and kills all of you,
The only person I ever know that shot at me, you know, I was in a lot of places where I got rockets and mortars and stuff like that, and they scared the hell out of me.
Nobody was trying to kill me.
They were trying to shoot up the place where I was.
But I was down in the Delta one time, and I flew into a...

an army air base down there you imagine the air force couldn't get me a ride to an air base i had to ride with the army to an army base and then they came from the air force base to pick me up the jeep to take me up to the air force base and we were driving through this marshland and there was a pagoda buddhist i guess out in the middle of this field very interesting looking thing i called other american
fighting men, the first thing I got when I went to war was a Japanese camera.
And so I got the driver to stop so I could get a picture of the thing and put it on the telephoto lens so I could really see it good.
And the first thing I saw was a kid, couldn't have been over 12, with a rifle pointed right back at my camera.
And it bounced around with a round of ammunition off the front of that jeep.
And I suggested to the sergeant, maybe we should go on.
All the pictures I needed to be able to go to.
And I was a little kid.
There's no way to justify that.
But you can understand how it happened.
Women and children were killing people.
And the ones that got killed may not have been the ones that were killing people, but you can understand why he got paranoid about that.
What, uh, what rank were you as a doctor?
Uh, that's all the questions I have prepared.
Is there anything you can think of that might be helpful to my study?
Any experiences or anything you want?
Check it out, I can't think of anything really.
I think if I can find that booklet, I'll get it to you and I think there might be some of the stats that you asked about in there.
And Jack Walker will be a good source for you.
He was also an internist, so some of the questions you asked about Vietnam-related diseases as opposed to injuries, I think I'm sure he could give you a lot better answers than I could.
Yeah, it's gotten a lot of valuable information.
You should have marked the following responses.
Now ask the following people if they are from the Spanish-speaking countries indicated.
T eres de Puerto Rico, Juanita?
Turn to your lab manual for activities 3, 4, and 5.
You will hear a question followed by two answers, A and B.
In your lab manual, activity 3, check the most appropriate answer for each question.
A. Estudio en la Universidad de Salamanca.
B. S, usted es de Honduras.
You should have marked A for numbers 2, 3, 5, 6, and 8.
You will hear a brief conversation between two people said twice.
You will probably not be able to understand every word in the conversation.
Listen carefully for the main ideas and facts.
Then read the series of either-or statements in your lab manual.
Place a check mark by statement A or B that seems to best correspond to the conversation.
Don't be afraid to guess the meaning of the cognates.
Yo soy el inspector de inmigracin.
Muy bien, estoy a su disposicin.
Yo soy el inspector de inmigracin.
Muy bien, estoy a su disposicin.
Now stop the tape and complete Activity 4 in your lab manual.
You should have marked A for one and B for two, three, four, and five.
You will hear a paragraph read twice.
In your lab manual, complete the paragraph by writing in the missing words.
Estudio en una universidad de los Estados Unidos, pero soy de Chile.
Estudio lenguas modernas, ingls y espaol.
Practico los lunes, mircoles y viernes en el laboratorio.
Mi padre es profesor de historia y mi madre es mdica del hospital de la universidad.
As you listen to the paragraph again, write the missing words in your lab manual.
Estudio en una universidad de los Estados Unidos, pero soy de Chile.
Estudio lenguas modernas, ingls y espaol.
I practice on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays in the laboratory.
My father is a history teacher.
Y mi madre es mdica del hospital de la universidad.
End of tape one, side B.

Made us dance across the room.
I said to myself when we're old.
We'll go dancing in the dark.
hurry don't be late i cannot wait i said to myself when we're old we'll go dancing in the dark walking through the park and reminiscing
Packing up the dreams God planted in the firm soil of you.
Can't believe the hopes he's granted.
Means a chapter in your life is through.
We'll keep you close as always.

Cause our hearts in big and small ways will keep the love that keeps us
